docs.lead_paragraph: Recently, while scheduling a doctor's visit for my daughter, the receptionist asked for a credit card to secure the appointment. The specialist didn't take insurance, charged $600 a visit and would charge my credit card if I canceled with less than 48 hours notice.
docs.abstract: Everybody is paying more out of pocket for health care nowadays, and many patients are now asking, "How can I get a better price?"
docs.snippet: Everybody is paying more out of pocket for health care nowadays, and many patients are now asking, "How can I get a better price?"

docs.lead_paragraph: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton.
docs.abstract: A conservative senator's recent comments about the new mammography guidelines help illuminate how America already "rations" health care, an economist writes.
docs.snippet: A conservative senator's recent comments about the new mammography guidelines help illuminate how America already "rations" health care, an economist writes.

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Bob Casey, whose father is known for having fought abortion, is a pivotal if reluctant player in the debate on public financing of abortions in the health bill.

headline.main: Universal Coverage: Choosing Decency and Vibrancy
headline.print_headline: Universal Coverage: Choosing Decency and Vibrancy

docs.lead_paragraph: Adrienne Schroeder recently moved to Richmond, Va., from Bozeman, Mont., to care for her aging father. Medical expenses -- not his, but hers -- are a concern. Ms. Schroeder had four pregnancies in the last six years, two ending in miscarriages. She still owes money from those medical costs, despite having had health insurance the whole time.
docs.abstract: Having health insurance does not preclude worrying about medical expenses; Adrienne Schroeder still owes money from previous pregnancy, despite having had health insurance; now out of work, she and husband pay $400 per month for private plan plus deductible of several thousand dollars; couple constantly looks for ways to cut medical costs; photo (S)
docs.snippet: Adrienne Schroeder recently moved to Richmond, Va., from Bozeman, Mont., to care for her aging father. Medical expenses -- not his, but hers -- are a concern.      Ms. Schroeder had four pregnancies in the last six years, two ending in miscarriages....

docs.lead_paragraph: Advocates of health care legislation are facing many challenges in getting their messages across to the public over the holidays. So one advocacy group is essentially moving its campaign to where the consumers are: stores and shopping malls. The group, Health Care for America Now, a coalition of labor and liberal activists, plans to drop leaflets at stores and malls Friday in Arizona, Missouri, Nevada and Texas. It says it hopes to ''educate'' shoppers about popular brands like Wrangler, the North Face and Nautica.
docs.abstract: Advocacy group Health Care for America Now will drop leaflets at stores and malls in Arizona, Missouri, Nevada and Texas to let consumers know that Eric Wiseman, chief executive of VF Corp, which markets popular clothing brands, also sits on board of Cigna health insurance company; group wants to expose Wiseman's role in blocking health care reform; photo (S)
